Doc: A type describing a set of dates defined as relative to another set of dates.

Source.Contents:
/#
   A type describing a set of dates defined as relative to another set of dates.
 #/
record FpML5.recordkeeping.RelativeDates {
  # A time period multiplier, e.g. 1, 2 or 3 etc. A negative value can be used when specifying an offset relative to another date, e.g. -2 days.
  periodMultiplier : int

  # A time period, e.g. a day, week, month or year of the stream. If the periodMultiplier value is 0 (zero) then period must contain the value D (day).
  period : string

  # In the case of an offset specified as a number of days, this element defines whether consideration is given as to whether a day is a good business day or not. If a day type of business days is specified then non-business days are ignored when calculating the offset. The financial business centers to use for determination of business days are implied by the context in which this element is used. This element must only be included when the offset is specified as a number of days. If the offset is zero days then the dayType element should not be included.
  dayType : string?

  # The convention for adjusting a date if it would otherwise fall on a day that is not a business day.
  businessDayConvention : string?

  # A pointer style reference to a set of financial business centers defined elsewhere in the document. This set of business centers is used to determine whether a particular day is a business day or not.
  businessCentersReference : FpML5.recordkeeping.BusinessCentersReference

  businessCenters : FpML5.recordkeeping.BusinessCenters

  # Specifies the anchor as an href attribute. The href attribute value is a pointer style reference to the element or component elsewhere in the document where the anchor date is defined.
  dateRelativeTo : FpML5.recordkeeping.DateReference?

  # The date once the adjustment has been performed. (Note that this date may change if the business center holidays change).
  adjustedDate : date?

  # The number of periods in the referenced date schedule that are between each date in the relative date schedule. Thus a skip of 2 would mean that dates are relative to every second date in the referenced schedule. If present this should have a value greater than 1.
  periodSkip : int( 1, * )?

  # The first and last dates of a schedule. This can be used to restrict the range of values in a reference series of dates.
  scheduleBounds : FpML5.recordkeeping.DateRange?

  id : string?

}

periodMultiplier.Doc: A time period multiplier, e.g. 1, 2 or 3 etc. A negative value can be used when specifying an offset relative to another date, e.g. -2 days.
periodMultiplier.Name: periodMultiplier

period.Doc: A time period, e.g. a day, week, month or year of the stream. If the periodMultiplier value is 0 (zero) then period must contain the value D (day).
period.Name: period

If a day type of business days is specified then non-business days are ignored when calculating the offset. The financial business centers to use for determination of business days are implied by the context in which this element is used. This element must only be included when the offset is specified as a number of days. If the offset is zero days then the dayType element should not be included.
dayType.Name: dayType

businessDayConvention.Name: businessDayConvention

businessCentersReference.Name: businessCentersReference

dateRelativeTo.Doc: Specifies the anchor as an href attribute. The href attribute value is a pointer style reference to the element or component elsewhere in the document where the anchor date is defined.
dateRelativeTo.Name: dateRelativeTo

adjustedDate.Doc: The date once the adjustment has been performed. (Note that this date may change if the business center holidays change).
adjustedDate.Name: adjustedDate

periodSkip.Doc: The number of periods in the referenced date schedule that are between each date in the relative date schedule. Thus a skip of 2 would mean that dates are relative to every second date in the referenced schedule. If present this should have a value greater than 1.
periodSkip.Name: periodSkip

scheduleBounds.Doc: The first and last dates of a schedule. This can be used to restrict the range of values in a reference series of dates.
scheduleBounds.Name: scheduleBounds
